rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBleeding edge documentation\u003c/a\u003e is also available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-background\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe purpose of Luigi is to address all the plumbing typically associated\nwith long-running batch processes. You want to chain many tasks,\nautomate them, and failures \u003cem\u003ewill\u003c/em\u003e happen. These tasks can be anything,\nbut are typically long running things like\n\u003ca href=\"http://hadoop.apache.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHadoop\u003c/a\u003e jobs, dumping data to/from\ndatabases, running machine learning algorithms, or anything else.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere are other software packages that focus on lower level aspects of\ndata processing, like \u003ca href=\"http://hive.apache.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHive\u003c/a\u003e,\n\u003ca href=\"http://pig.apache.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePig\u003c/a\u003e, or\n\u003ca href=\"http://www.cascading.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eCascading\u003c/a\u003e. Luigi is not a framework to\nreplace these. Instead it helps you stitch many tasks together, where\neach task can be a \u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hive.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHive query\u003c/a\u003e,\na \u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hadoop_jar.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHadoop job in Java\u003c/a\u003e,\na  \u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.spark.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSpark job in Scala or Python\u003c/a\u003e,\na Python snippet,\n\u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.sqla.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edumping a table\u003c/a\u003e\nfrom a database, or anything else. It's easy to build up\nlong-running pipelines that comprise thousands of tasks and take days or\nweeks to complete. Luigi takes care of a lot of the workflow management\nso that you can focus on the tasks themselves and their dependencies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou can build pretty much any task you want, but Luigi also comes with a\n\u003cem\u003etoolbox\u003c/em\u003e of several common task templates that you use. It includes\nsupport for running\n\u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hadoop.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePython mapreduce jobs\u003c/a\u003e\nin Hadoop, as well as\n\u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hive.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHive\u003c/a\u003e,\nand \u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.pig.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePig\u003c/a\u003e,\njobs. It also comes with\n\u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hdfs.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efile system abstractions for HDFS\u003c/a\u003e,\nand local files that ensures all file system operations are atomic. This\nis important because it means your data pipeline will not crash in a\nstate containing partial data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-visualiser-page\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv dir=\"auto\"\u003eJust to give you an idea of what Luigi does, this is a screen shot from\nsomething we are running in production. Using Luigi's visualiser, we get\na nice visual overview of the dependency graph of the workflow. Each\nnode represents a task which has to be run. Green tasks are already\ncompleted whereas yellow tasks are yet to be run. Most of these tasks\nare Hadoop jobs, but there are also some things that run locally and\nbuild up data files.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer nofollow\" href=\"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/spotify/luigi/master/doc/user_recs.png\"\u003e\u003cimg alt=\"Dependency graph\" src=\"https://raw.githubusercontent.com/spotify/luigi/master/doc/user_recs.png\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-philosophy\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003ePhilosophy\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-philosophy\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Philosophy\" href=\"#philosophy\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eConceptually, Luigi is similar to \u003ca href=\"http://www.gnu.org/software/make/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGNU\nMake\u003c/a\u003e where you have certain tasks\nand these tasks in turn may have dependencies on other tasks. There are\nalso some similarities to \u003ca href=\"http://oozie.apache.org/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOozie\u003c/a\u003e\nand \u003ca href=\"https://azkaban.github.io/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAzkaban\u003c/a\u003e. One major\ndifference is that Luigi is not just built specifically for Hadoop, and\nit's easy to extend it with other kinds of tasks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eEverything in Luigi is in Python. Instead of XML configuration or\nsimilar external data files, the dependency graph is specified \u003cem\u003ewithin\nPython\u003c/em\u003e. This makes it easy to build up complex dependency graphs of\ntasks, where the dependencies can involve date algebra or recursive\nreferences to other versions of the same task. However, the workflow can\ntrigger things not in Python, such as running\n\u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.pig.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePig scripts\u003c/a\u003e\nor \u003ca href=\"https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.ssh.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003escp'ing files\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ca name=\"user-content-who-uses-luigi\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eWho uses Luigi?\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-who-uses-luigi\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Who uses Luigi?\" href=\"#who-uses-luigi\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe use Luigi internally at \u003ca href=\"https://www.spotify.com\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSpotify\u003c/a\u003e to run\nthousands of tasks every day, organized in complex dependency graphs.\nMost of these tasks are Hadoop jobs. Luigi provides an infrastructure\nthat powers all kinds of stuff including recommendations, toplists, A/B\ntest analysis, external reports, internal dashboards, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSince Luigi is open source and without any registration walls, the exact number\nof Luigi users is unknown. But based on the number of unique contributors, we\nexpect hundreds of enterprises to use it. src="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/8e8930720468167d576d7f2d9b7cdc9036f242745bef486a83754344715197f3/68747470733a2f2f72656164746865646f63732e6f72672f70726f6a656374732f6c756967692f62616467652f3f76657273696f6e3d737461626c65" data-canonical-src="https://readthedocs.org/projects/luigi/badge/?version=stable" style="max-width: 100%;"></a><p dir="auto">Luigi is a Python (3.6, 3.7, 3.8, 3.9, 3.10, 3.11 tested) package that helps you build complexpipelines of batch jobs. It handles dependency resolution, workflow management,visualization, handling failures, command line integration, and much more.</p><a name="user-content-getting-started"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Getting Started</h2><a id="user-content-getting-started" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Getting Started" href="#getting-started"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Run <code>pip install luigi</code> to install the latest stable version from <a href="https://pypi.python.org/pypi/luigi" rel="nofollow">PyPI</a>. <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/stable/" rel="nofollow">Documentation for the latest release</a> is hosted on readthedocs.</p><p dir="auto">Run <code>pip install luigi[toml]</code> to install Luigi with <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/stable/configuration.html" rel="nofollow">TOML-based configs</a> support.</p><p dir="auto">For the bleeding edge code, <code>pip installgit+https://github.com/spotify/luigi.git</code>. <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/" rel="nofollow">Bleeding edge documentation</a> is also available.</p><a name="user-content-background"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Background</h2><a id="user-content-background" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Background" href="#background"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">The purpose of Luigi is to address all the plumbing typically associatedwith long-running batch processes. You want to chain many tasks,automate them, and failures <em>will</em> happen. These tasks can be anything,but are typically long running things like<a href="http://hadoop.apache.org/" rel="nofollow">Hadoop</a> jobs, dumping data to/fromdatabases, running machine learning algorithms, or anything else.</p><p dir="auto">There are other software packages that focus on lower level aspects ofdata processing, like <a href="http://hive.apache.org/" rel="nofollow">Hive</a>,<a href="http://pig.apache.org/" rel="nofollow">Pig</a>, or<a href="http://www.cascading.org/" rel="nofollow">Cascading</a>. Luigi is not a framework toreplace these. Instead it helps you stitch many tasks together, whereeach task can be a <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hive.html" rel="nofollow">Hive query</a>,a <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hadoop_jar.html" rel="nofollow">Hadoop job in Java</a>,a  <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.spark.html" rel="nofollow">Spark job in Scala or Python</a>,a Python snippet,<a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.sqla.html" rel="nofollow">dumping a table</a>from a database, or anything else. It's easy to build uplong-running pipelines that comprise thousands of tasks and take days orweeks to complete. Luigi takes care of a lot of the workflow managementso that you can focus on the tasks themselves and their dependencies.</p><p dir="auto">You can build pretty much any task you want, but Luigi also comes with a<em>toolbox</em> of several common task templates that you use. It includessupport for running<a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hadoop.html" rel="nofollow">Python mapreduce jobs</a>in Hadoop, as well as<a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hive.html" rel="nofollow">Hive</a>,and <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.pig.html" rel="nofollow">Pig</a>,jobs. It also comes with<a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.hdfs.html" rel="nofollow">file system abstractions for HDFS</a>,and local files that ensures all file system operations are atomic. Thisis important because it means your data pipeline will not crash in astate containing partial data.</p><a name="user-content-visualiser-page"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Visualiser page</h2><a id="user-content-visualiser-page" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Visualiser page" href="#visualiser-page"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Just to give you an idea of what Luigi does, this is a screen shot fromsomething we are running in production. Using Luigi's visualiser, we geta nice visual overview of the dependency graph of the workflow. Eachnode represents a task which has to be run. Green tasks are alreadycompleted whereas yellow tasks are yet to be run. Most of these tasksare Hadoop jobs, but there are also some things that run locally andbuild up data files.</p><div dir="auto"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" href="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/spotify/luigi/master/doc/user_recs.png"><img alt="Dependency graph" src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/spotify/luigi/master/doc/user_recs.png" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></div><a name="user-content-philosophy"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Philosophy</h2><a id="user-content-philosophy" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Philosophy" href="#philosophy"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Conceptually, Luigi is similar to <a href="http://www.gnu.org/software/make/" rel="nofollow">GNUMake</a> where you have certain tasksand these tasks in turn may have dependencies on other tasks. There arealso some similarities to <a href="http://oozie.apache.org/" rel="nofollow">Oozie</a>and <a href="https://azkaban.github.io/" rel="nofollow">Azkaban</a>. One majordifference is that Luigi is not just built specifically for Hadoop, andit's easy to extend it with other kinds of tasks.</p><p dir="auto">Everything in Luigi is in Python. Instead of XML configuration orsimilar external data files, the dependency graph is specified <em>withinPython</em>. This makes it easy to build up complex dependency graphs oftasks, where the dependencies can involve date algebra or recursivereferences to other versions of the same task. However, the workflow cantrigger things not in Python, such as running<a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.pig.html" rel="nofollow">Pig scripts</a>or <a href="https://luigi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/api/luigi.contrib.ssh.html" rel="nofollow">scp'ing files</a>.</p><a name="user-content-who-uses-luigi"></a><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Who uses Luigi?</h2><a id="user-content-who-uses-luigi" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Who uses Luigi?" href="#who-uses-luigi"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">We use Luigi internally at <a href="https://www.spotify.com" rel="nofollow">Spotify</a> to runthousands of tasks every day, organized in complex dependency graphs.Most of these tasks are Hadoop jobs. Luigi provides an infrastructurethat powers all kinds of stuff including recommendations, toplists, A/Btest analysis, external reports, internal dashboards, etc.</p><p dir="auto">Since Luigi is open source and without any registration walls, the exact numberof Luigi users is unknown. But based on the number of unique contributors, weexpect hundreds of enterprises to use it.
